Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation2: The site-wide evacuation alarm has just sounded, and you must stop everything and proceed to the muster point immediately.
Story: I was stacking bricks when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from Mom: “Dad’s not feeling well. Can you call?” I glanced at the foreman, who was shouting for everyone to drop their tools and head to the muster point—the evacuation alarm was blaring. My heart pounded. I knew the rules: no phones, no delays, just move. But I also knew how much my parents relied on me, especially when things felt uncertain at home. I wanted to call, to hear Mom’s voice and reassure her, to be the son they needed. But the team was already moving, and I could feel the eyes of my coworkers on me, expecting me to follow. I stood frozen, torn between the urgent call of family and the strict demands of the site. My phone vibrated again in my hand, and I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in, each demanding something I wasn’t sure I could give.
